Real stories
"Without a name" has a somewhat unusual starting point. The screenwriters have talked to a number of addicts and relatives, and then write a text based on these conversations. The play is thus based on the real world, in real man and stories - at the same time it has become a real (art) work.
Often, something happens in the transmission when one is trying to put in writing the oral stories of human beings in writing. (Try it yourself. It is very difficult to make good stories work on paper.)
Some of the really impressive and nice in "Without a Name", how both text and presentation are so close to the way I speak, like telling stories, that you periodically forget that there are shoe players standing there and presenting a text that's her pug. That it is actually the father of Paul who stands there. And that he tells a true story.
Because that's how people tell stories. Not perfect, but occasionally sobering, but not quite able to find the right words. Not just sad, but with a glimpse of warmth and humor in the tragedy, paradoxical situations, strange memories that suddenly emerge.
But it is extremely difficult to write, direct and present a text that is just that. So close, so close, so superficial, so "real".

It is the relatives' perspective with meetings in "Without Name". There are many addicts in Norway - but far more relatives. Here, I get to meet a father, a brother, a sister, a child, a wife, all those who try to help, try to understand, all those who get dragged into the suction that occurs when a man goes to sleep.

They do so against a simple, but beautiful, light wall that changes color and shades all the time. And with a conscious use of music and sound, sometimes quiet in the background, other times loud and intense.
It is a constant debate that theater should "go into time" and say something about contemporary. Sometimes one closes, whether the text is old or new, other times not.
